title: What will be the total domestic box office gross for Disney’s Mulan as of 8 September 2020, according to Box Office Mojo?
possible_answers: More than $70 million but less than $140 million
preds:
Disney moved “Mulan” from movie theaters to premium release on Disney+ [1]
[1] https://www.thewrap.com/mulan-ad-destroyed-theater-owner-disney-pulls-film/

Here is a question. Does ‘Box Office’ include Disney Plus streaming? Theaters will not be making money at the Box Office. Asked for clarification.  Mulan will be released on Disney Plus on September 4th. Users will have to pay an extra $30 to watch Mulan. Hard to find how many US subscribers. Leaving until clarification.

I think $1 Million could easy be reached and /or surpassed in 4 days via $30 rentals from current Disney + members.   I would assume most of those members have children who will also be pushing to see this movie.  I know mine are.
Only 34,000 people need to pay the $30 fee over the four days from its release to earn $1 million which is plausible given the current number of subscribers is approximately 50 million.
Mulan is skipping theaters completely so there is no way it makes any box office this year.

Following the definition of box office gross is for tickets sold and the question only concerns domestic (US) then the receipts are minimal, considering that Disney have pulled Mulan from the theatres and gone to Disney+ only. https://www.thewrap.com/mulan-ad-destroyed-theater-owner-disney-pulls-film/  http://www.mediasalles.it/ybk07adv/tabelle/img_tabelle/tab_img_7_def_en.html

"Mulan is set to get a worldwide streaming release on Disney Plus. From September 4 the film will be available for a US$30 fee in territories around the world with access to Disney Plus." https://newatlas.com/home-entertainment/mulan-tenet-future-cinema-theatrical-digital-disney-warner/
A big IF it is released by September 8th. It won't have the usual Disney release gross if they decide to stream and also because its live-action.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-film-mulan/disneys-mulan-to-skip-most-movie-theaters-for-streaming-idUSKCN2502VO If BoxOfcMojo doesn't include streaming revenue, there is no chance of a million bucks.  If it does, a million is well within reach.  Does anybody know anything about this?

It will be released in Sept in some international theaters and on Disney+ [1], where it is possible to do so (i.e. China). For a fee on Disney+, that is: "the studio will release Mulan on Disney+ ON SEPTEMBER 4 for an additional fee (what the studio is calling a "Premiere Access") of $29.99." [2]  Also good to note that "global subscribers for Disney+ has reached 60.5 million" [1]. I am assuming that BoxOffice Mojo will not be reporting streaming numbers. [1] https://deadline.com/2020/08/mulan-new-release-date-disney-earnings-call-1203003942/
[2] https://www.inverse.com/entertainment/mulan-disney-plus-release-date-price-subscription

"Disney and the Disney-owned Fox Searchlight have removed Mulan ... from their upcoming theatrical release calendars indefinitely in response to the continuing coronavirus pandemic." https://www.vulture.com/2020/07/mulan-release-date-french-dispatch-release-date-postponed.html
No set release date.  Cinemas unlikely to open.  Kids film.  Very low chance of making any Monet before Sept 8.
Postponed indefinitely according to latest reports.
This movie is not opening anytime soon.
Release postponed indefinitely from (the scheduled) August 21, 2020. This makes a release before September 8 difficult. Hence moving 95% to the first bucket.

https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/07/23/amc-theatres-reopening-delayed-covid-19-cases-tenet-mulan/5492525002/  I don’t think they would’ve pushed it this far back if they didn’t expect an additional delay for the Mulan release. They’ll need to be operating a minimum of 2-3 weeks to work the kinks out prior to managing a blockbuster release.

Movie theaters are postponing their opening date [1]
[1] https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2020/07/cinemark-delays-opening-movie-theaters-again.html

"“Mulan” would need around $300 million" in ticket sales to break-even [1]. And so it is expected that Mulan will probably delay again. We've seen the question bumped once for a change in date. Can we expect it again? [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/16/these-charts-show-why-studios-are-likely-to-delay-tenet-and-mulan.html
Increasing 1st bucket by another 5% based on Tenet’s delay announcement today. Major market theaters are nowhere near ready to open and effectively handle a blockbuster release.
Release date now 21st august.  Only 18 days available.  Just how many people will be going to the cinema?  Not a lot.  Revising forecast down! A lot.

New article suggests further delay in movie releasing [1]
[1] https://nypost.com/2020/07/13/summer-blockbusters-tenet-and-mulan-likely-delayed-again/
Anticipating another delay to be announced this week: https://variety.com/2020/film/news/tenet-box-office-coronavirus-mulan-1234704739/
6th July: Box office collection numbers are still negligent. No new news on release date
As daily covid cases increase in USA, I will keep increasing the probability for '< than $1 million' bucket

Bumping <$1M bucket a little further.  Strong sense that the landscape will not be conducive to even the August date, primarily with respect to current trends and news out of California and New York. For both the production houses as well as the theaters, at some point I think it is quite likely (perhaps 55-65%) that they will stop screwing around with incremental punts on opening, which is an expensive proposition in terms of keeping everything "warm" so to speak, and will punt out considerably further to a safer timeframe.  https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/why-movie-theater-chains-unlikely-130020507.html
https://www.screendaily.com/news/california-governor-tells-los-angeles-county-cinemas-to-remain-closed/5151248.article
https://deadline.com/2020/06/ny-gov-andrew-cuomo-movie-theaters-malls-gyms-phase-4-covid-cases-spike-states-1202969792/
Increasing the less than $1mm bucket to hedge against an additional delay in the release date.
Increasing the less than $1mm bucket to hedge against an additional delay in the release date.

More delay expected to be considered after July 4th weekend
https://lrmonline.com/news/mulan-and-tenet-could-get-pushed-to-september/
Pumping on bin1 due to below article, which scenario seems increasingly likely. https://www.cbr.com/mulan-tenet-august-releases-september/

Opening has been delayed to Aug 21st [1]. Movie theaters are delaying their reopenings, with AMC waiting until the end of July [2]. Also, a number of states have put them quite far out in reopening. Even if Mulan sticks to the Aug 21st date, there may not be many places to watch it. Moving down   [1] https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/6/29/21307335/coronavirus-disney-mulan-covid-19-pandemic
[2] https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/06/29/885064546/with-big-summer-films-delayed-amc-theatres-puts-off-u-s-reopening

Same as Tenet but + 5% switched between first 2 options. If Tenet will be released 12/08, they can see the $’s and still decide to postpone because of it. Have to watch how situation changes and nr’s from other countries, that have covid under control, but still  only open up at < 50% capacity + strict measures (facemask, snackshop closed,...)

Updating my probabilities for Disney moving the release date to very close to Sept 8 (and the concern they may move it again): https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/6/29/21307335/coronavirus-disney-mulan-covid-19-pandemic
Release delayed to August 21 per Variety. https://variety.com/2020/film/box-office/mulan-release-postponed-coronavirus-disney-1234576142/

Mulan release date moved back to Aug 21 (h/t @jainsa [1]), giving it 3 weekends before the Sept 8 question close date. HSX 4-week [2] is at $151 million, suggesting $56 million opening weekend and likely to get into the third bin after three weekends. Still leaving a small chance it gets delayed again. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1066789
[2] https://www.hsx.com/security/view/MULN
Expecting Mulan to be postponed (at least by 4 weeks?).  Hence modifying my forecasts.

Same logic as update today for similar Tenet question, below. There are some nuances between the two, yes, but close enough. :-) ***** Forecast submitted seconds ago notwithstanding, and now talking out the other side of my mouth, I see a considerable (50%+) probability that over the next few weeks, state governments (at least in high-population states) continue to reckon w/ the fact that reopening is happening way too fast, and that new broadly adopted best practices will keep movie theaters shut in these larger states through the end of the year. If movie theaters in large states aren't open, Tenet doesn't open within subject timeframe. I'm a little worried that I'm over-revving on this, but my longterm weighted averages are heavily skewed toward my prior views, so a few days at the above allocations won't hurt too much if the above scenario doesn't come to pass. However, there is also a scenario where the above does not come to pass, but movie theaters don't think there will be enough traffic for it to be worth opening. This appears to be playing out in CA [1], which along with NY [2], are the two most important theater markets. Prior articles have indicated that if those two markets aren't open, Tenet will not release... [3] [1] https://deadline.com/2020/06/california-movie-theater-reopening-1202954538/
[2] https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-york-postpones-reopenings-of-malls-movie-theaters-and-gyms-11593033187
[3] https://screenrant.com/mulan-tenet-release-date-delayed-ny-movie-theaters/

This film is unlikely to open as theaters as going to remain closed in most states. The ones that might have like Texas or Florida are seeing a surge in cases right now, so that is very doubtful this movie opens this year at all.

It’s a kids movie and people are desperate to find things for their kids to do. Additionally, I can easily see Disney pulling a direct to streaming for a fee on this movie if it doesn’t do well in theaters.

Editing up a bit because there are so few movies that will be available.  I don’t see a huge opening crowd, but I do see a heavy trend for those who choose to go.  For following my perceptions, I am in a “vulnerable “ category and don’t see movie theaters in my near future.

Lot depends on if the movie will be released in the theaters or not. Theater collects are at ~.4% of the previous year collection
China is another big target market for this movie and the movie theaters are not open in China yet. No new movie trailer released by Disney recently. I have a feeling that movie release will be postponed to Christmas

Weekly total domestic box office continues to rise. Shouldn’t be a problem to break $1 million assuming actual release is near the current announced release date. Breaking $70 million is a stretch given current Covid-19 concerns and multiple states not getting new cases under control.
I just don't trust Americans to stay home. That said, some places will not be experiencing the same amount of cases as others, so it's much safer to go to the movies.
Parents with children will be hesitant to go to the movies because of Covid.
I believe the release will be pushed because theaters will be closed due to covid
One of three theater chains is already open. More and more states are allowing opening of theaters. Probability of movie getting released in theaters is increasing.
China just shuttered their theaters again. Unsure if any will open at all this year.
Just seems like a horrible idea to go to movie theater packed with people, but people seem hellbent on returning to “normal”.
I love going to the movies and there is no way in hell I am setting foot in one any time soon. BO will drop in half for any new release.
1st major Disney film to be released online.
Theater sales will Be depressed due to coronavirus through September
Limited theater openings combined with people’s fears, but desire to get out. People will go, but limited searing will limit $
Seems less likely that the movie's opening date will be pushed.

Very similar logic to my forecast regarding Tenet box office gross [1]. The way the bins are bracketed, I don’t think the various differing factors between the two movies (relevant comps, anticipated release date, etc.) really matter. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1030993k

Used Aladdin and Beauty and the Beast as comps (feel like Lion King is "too mainstream" to compare with Mulan): Aladdin: Opening Weekend: $91m, Total: $355m
Beauty and the Beast: Opening Weekend $175m, Total: $505m (much better than I remembered the box office being)  Kids seem to be "less affected" by the virus and parents want to get kids out of the house, so maybe more likely to take them to the movies? Will all 50 states have theaters open? According to this article, Disney is still planning to release Mulan in July, but so much can change between now and July, still think there is a shot they push the film. https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/5/11/21254833/coronavirus-covid-19-mulan-release-date-bob-chapek
Using same logic as the question about Tenet for now. Will need to update both pretty frequently.
We could all be back in lock down by July. People not necessarily going to congregate. Difficult. Will need updating.

The total for the live action Beauty in the Beast was $1.264 billion [1]. If, based on a SWAG, we say that half the theaters are open and they can fill 1/3rd of the seats, that puts it at around $200 million assuming B&tB numbers are attainable by Mulan. I'll consider that the top end and put the center in the bucket below. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_(2017_film)

https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/movies/2020/05/05/coronavirus-disney-keeps-mulan-july-release-fingers-crossed/5171485002/
Hard to know. A resurgence might scare everyone away or only 30% occupancy alliwed. Lowering some from top.

If released as originally planned, Mulan would have made $165M in April (https://www.forbes.com/sites/travisbean/2020/04/14/would-2020-have-had-the-best-april-ever-a-box-office-breakdown/#c8e34b85aec2), 1 month after release.  At best, it wouldn't have passed $210M.  This indicates that $140M - $210M at best of times would have been most likely (now very unlikely).  Assuming a social distance factor 0.5 for social distancing brings this number to $85M roughly for a best case.
Less than a million if forced to a digital release (disney+). But if theatres are functioning at 50% capacity or more, turnout will be very high as families look for entertainment and escapism.

This could go to Disney +, or be delayed                          - hence 25% for less than USD 1 million
A release would pretty much put them in bucket 2       - hence 62% for between USD 1 million and USD 70 million
Chances of doing USD 70M to USD 140M are slim        - hence 13% for between USD 70 million and USD 140 million Above USD 140 million is pretty difficult - assuming that 25% of seats are being sold, that would mean a box office of around USD 600 million in normal times. For comparison - the Lion King has a domestic gross of USD 520 million over a 40 day period.  BTW - Does anyone have a split of the US (or North American) box office/screens by state? Would love to take a look if possible.

If Disney releases the movie, there will be enough countries that will have ended the lockdowns out of necessity or otherwise to support a wide theatrical release. Moreover, people crave normalcy and don't naturally fear what they can't see.

Under normal circumstances,  Mulan would be a cert to hit $140 million and likely to go past $210 million. Taking Lion King and Aladdin as comps Mulan would need to do around 40% of LK's gross and around 67% of Aladdin's gross. While the original animations of these two films were more popular and than Mulan, it seems reasonable to believe Mulan would hit the $210 mill mark. However, these aren't normal circumstances: - There is no clarity on when cinemas will reopen en masse.
- Social distancing rules might be enacted in certain states (or cinema chains) limiting audience numbers. There is potential Disney will delay the film if this scenario transpires.
- Sections of the public might be wary of large gatherings even if restrictions are completely lifted. Lion King: https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl3321923073/weekly/?ref_=bo_rl_tab#tabs
Aladdin: https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl3246360065/weekly/?ref_=bo_rl_tab#tabs
initial quote just based on feeling. to be refined later on. Very much driven by question bands.

Kids love Disney movies, and by July they'll be climbing the walls and their parent's nerves will be shot. Parents will be emptying their bank accounts to buy tickets just so they can have a few hours of peace and quiet while their kids are at the movies. However, I don't expect all theaters to be open and I suspect that some parents will still be unreasonably overprotective of their offspring and unwilling to risk their kid's health for a few hours peace, so although I think Mulan will gross over $100M domestic in its first month I think the chance for over $200M is somewhat lower.

Current HSX opening weekend stock [1] is at $57.26, indicating a $57 million opening weekend, and its full 4-week price [2] [3] is at 162.03 million, both of which seem hard to fathom right now, so I'm hedging toward bin 2 with 50% in bins 3 and 4. [1] https://www.hsx.com/security/view/MULN.OW
[2] https://www.hsx.com/security/view/MULN
[3] https://www.kaigee.com/MST/MULN

In Texas, which plans to reopen theatres in four days, governor Greg Abbott has set a capacity limit of 25% for each individual theatre. https://www.ibc.org/consume/us-cinema-chains-to-remain-shut-despite-easing-of-lockdown-rules/5835.article https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl3246360065/ - Aladin stats if prospects are low they will not release it in cinemas and put it on for stream If it does go out to cinema it will be hugely popular post lock down
Some states are just starting to partially reopen; others have reopening plans. Mindsets to go to the theater will vary on a number of factors including where people live.
Lots of people will still be staying home, plus many movie theaters may not reopen
The issue clearly is COVID-19. If the prospect is too bad, Disney won't release the movie to the cinemas and will instead publish it to Disney+.

Looking at some other live action remakes.
Dumbo (2019) had a domestic opening weekend of $45m
Lion King (2019) has a domestic opening weekend of $191m
My instinct is the remake figures are driven by nostalgia over the originals and there is more nostalgia for Lion King than Dumbo (as the people who grew up with the original Dumbo are much older). Mulan, doesn’t feel like it holds the same nostalgic appeal.
The question relates to a 45-day period from opening (assuming the date doesn’t change).
My instinct is an opening weekend of around $50m, so will the remaining days allow it to go above $25m to get into the next range of 70m-140m? It doesn’t require much of viewing to do that, and even if there are fewer theatres open than normal then I think that post Covid-19 people will be more inclined to want to do activities outside of the house.

This prediction is difficult, because I think it's likely that the movie never gets released in theaters and goes straight to a Disney+ exclusive. If it is to be released it will make nowhere near other similar live action movies released last year some like the lion king which almost surpassed 210 million in the US alone on opening weekend. Many movie theaters at the moment are totally closed and the few that are attempting to work out the logistics of reopening should be expecting their capacity limit to at least halve. Movie theaters should expect a heavy decline in attendance even if they are able to completely reopen due to the cleanliness of theater and the rise in popularity of streaming platforms during quarantine. Also with unemployment rates rising and people being put in more dire financial situations not many people would spend unnecessary money while putting their lives at risk.

It seems unlikely to me that movie theaters will be open in July. Even if some other areas of the economy can reopen, movie theaters are tight, enclosed spaces: perfectly wrong for combating COVID. If some reopen, I think the movie will be popular enough to exceed $70 million, but limited release and residual COVID fears will limit the likelihood of it being a smash hit (>$210 million). These answers could change somewhat if Disney opted to make the movie available on-demand, but I think given the spectacle nature of the movie, Disney would be more likely to delay the release again past September than to do that.
